Award.AwardTitle: Molecular Level Studies on Phthalates at Interfaces Using Nonlinear Optical Spectroscopic Techniques
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Environmental Chemical Sciences (ECS) program of the Division of Chemistry will support the research program of Prof. Zhan Chen of the University of Michigan. Prof. Chan and his students will employ sum frequency generation (SFG) and coherent anti-Stokes Raman scattering (CARS) spectroscopy to reveal segregation and molecular structures of phthalates, which are commonly used plasticizers, on polymer surfaces and on environmentally important model surfaces/interfaces. The study aims to increase our understanding of degradation mechanisms of phthalates on surfaces and in bulk media, and to elucidate molecular mechanisms of various surface modification methods to prevent/reduce phthalate leaching from polymer systems.


The study will probe for the first time the interfacial behavior of phthalates at environmentally important surfaces and interfaces in situ. It will provide molecular correlations between phthalate structure on environmentally relevant surfaces and interfaces and their leaching and degradation properties. The project will ultimately aid in the design and development of methodologies to reduce and minimize phthalates' negative impacts on the environment and human health. The study will provide an excellent educational opportunity for undergraduate and graduate students to carry out a fundamental research project of great societal importance.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this research, we successfully used a nonlinear optical spectroscopic technique, sum frequency generation (SFG) vibrational spectroscopy, to examine molecular structures of surfaces and interfaces of phthalate plasticized poly(vinyl chloride) (PVC) polymer, supplemented by secondary ion mass spectrometry (SIMS) and contact angle goniometry. At the same time, we applied coherent anti-Stokes Raman scattering (CARS) and Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) to study the bulk structures of these materials. We elucidated the surface and bulk molecular behaviors of a variety of plasticized PVC materials as a function of phthalate bulk concentrations and annealing conditions in different chemical environments in situ and in real time. More importantly, we revealed the effects of various treatments such as plasma treatment, UV-light irradiation, UV-light irradiation with H2O2 solution, microwave exposure, solvent extraction, and surface grafting on the reduction and prevention of plasticizer leaching from PVC. A molecular level understanding of phthalate leaching from the PVC polymers into the surrounding environment was obtained. This research developed methodology to study surface, interfacial, and bulk structures of the same sample in the same environment using vibrational spectroscopic techniques, making contributions to the applications of spectroscopic methods in analytical chemistry and physical chemistry. The knowledge obtained from this study on molecular leaching behaviors of phthalate plasticizers and the leaching reduction and prevention methods impacts environmental chemistry and surface/interfacial chemistry studies. This research developed in-depth understanding on the structure-property relationships of phthalate plasticized PVC materials. Additionally, a series of “green” non-phthalate plasticizers such as various citrates, were also investigated and their molecular surface and bulk behaviors were elucidated. The important knowledge obtained from the studies on phthalate plasticized PVC and PVC with “green” plasticizers in this research will facilitate the design and development of PVC materials with plasticizers with minimal negative environmental impact.  

This highly interdisciplinary research provided training and education opportunities for the postdoc and the graduate students who worked on this project in many research areas, preparing them for employment in the related fields in the future. Other postdocs and graduate students in the PI’s group also gained important knowledge generated from this project through group meeting presentations and discussions. Since plasticized PVC polymers are widely used in our society, in applications such as medical devices, construction materials, and even toys, the understanding of phthalate leaching behaviors and the methodology developed to reduce and prevent phthalate leaching will benefit our society as a whole. The PI also included the results obtained from this project in his graduate and undergraduate analytical chemistry courses as well as a two-week long summer surface chemistry course for high school students to educate more students.
